## **Take the drafts out of the drawer!** {.text-left .unselectable .azultitulo}
## {.unnumbered .text-right .unselectable}
:::: {.text-left .unselectable}
::: {.column-left .column width="45%"}
\   When you uncover a draft or project, you have several steps to organize:

1. Organize data
2. Update statistical models
3. Think about how to present the results
4. Review what you have already written
5. Prepare the submission
\  ... and much more!

## **Clarify and organize them!** {.text-left .unselectable .rubrotitulo}
## {.unnumbered .text-left .unselectable}
\   Regardless of the project you are developing, or what phase it is in, do not let difficulties hinder progress:

1. Many concurrent disciplines reducing the available time
2. Difficulty with data collection and analysis
3. Good scientific writing takes time!
4. Review the manuscript
5. ... and more! 
:::
::::

# {.unnumbered .text-center .unselectable .espacomaior}

\ The consultant-client relationship has important and necessary functional traits, especially the mutual trust in each other: from the availability of data to the performance of a service by the consultant.  
</br>
\ The building of this trust is continually established between them, but previous experiences, whether experiences that have been successful or unsuccessful or even recommendations from third parties are factors that can influence this relationship before it even begins.  
</br>

#### *Data analysis*  
##### *Descriptive analysis*  
\   
1. Mean ($\mu$), mode and median  
2. Standard Error  
3. Standard deviation ($\sigma$)  
4. Confidence interval  
3. Variable classification and optimization  
4. Data distributions  
5. Residual analysis  
6. Hypothesis tests (**H~0~**: e **H~A~**:)  
7. *Network Analysis* - at networkd or vertices levels  
</br>
</br>

##### *Statistical modelling*  

Models specifically used according to the data fit.  
   
1. T-test  
1. Chi-square ($\chi$^2^)  
1. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)  
1. Linear regression  
1. Linear correlation   
1. Logistic regression   
1. Linear models (LM)  
2. Generalized linear models (GLM)  
3. Mixed linear models (LMM)  
4. Generalized mixed linear models (GLMM)  
5. Generalized additive models (GAM)  
6. Generalized additive and mixed models (GAMM)  
7. Non-linear regression (NLM)  
</br>
</br>
</br>

## **Who am I?** {.azultitulo}
## {.unnumbered .text-left .unselectable}
\ 

:::: {style="display: flex;" .unselectable}
::: {.column-justify .column width="70%"}
\   My name is Gudryan Baronio, I am a biologist graduated in 2010 at Brazilian University called Universidade Federal do Mato Grosso do Sul. I completed my master's  (2013) and doctorate degrees (2017) in Ecology and Conservation of Natural Resources in Universidade Federal de Uberlândia. If you want to consult my [complete curriculum](http://lattes.cnpq.br/7041242762452086) or [Research Gate](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Gudryan-J-Baronio), you can see that I have worked a good part of my academic life with interactions among plants and animals.
\
\   Among the main interests are: how the understanding of these interactions, mutualistic and antagonistic, are shaped and maintained in the communities according to the availability and use of resources by the interactants, as well as the direct and indirect effects resulting from these interactions. Great concerns for meeting these interests are always to identify what data to collect, how to collect and analyze it, and obviously, how to present the results.

For this, I developed some skills, such as:  
\   
<span style="color:blue"> 
\   - Statistical analysis and graphical tools  
\   
\   - Programming language(*R* and *Python*)  
\   
\   - Scientific writing  
\   
</span>
:::

\   Particularly, I am organization-friendly and this certainly will be reflected in the way I offer and carry out my work. Scientific activities must be rigorous and standardized, especially in the acquisition and manipulation of data, and of course, in the presentation of results.
